Stem: Which items do you think will be attracted to a magnet? Select all that apply.
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) a crayon, B) a fork, C) a screw, D) a candle, E) a taki chip, F) a paper clip
Scenario Justification: No scenario. Simple identification of magnetic objects.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall/recognition.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of which materials are magnetic.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Add an experimental context where students must predict and then evaluate results.

Stem: Which image shows the magnets repelling?
Image/Diagram Description: Two images showing different magnet configurations.
Choices: A) Image 1, B) Image 2
Scenario Justification: Simple visual identification of magnet interactions.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Visual recognition.
DCI Justification: Tests ability to identify repulsion from a diagram.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Only 2 answer choices — below standard. Add data from magnetic force investigations.

Stem: What 2 forces are acting on the book?
Image/Diagram Description: Image of a book sitting on a surface.
Choices: A) magnetic force, B) touching force, C) electric force, D) gravity, E) heat force
Scenario Justification: Simple visual scenario with a book at rest.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Force identification recall.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that gravity pulls book down and surface pushes up (contact force).
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (gravity pulls down + surface pushes up → balanced forces → book stays still).
Key Recommendation: Provide data from force measurement experiments and ask students to analyze balanced forces.

Stem: Puppy Traits passage (ReadWorks): What do genes do?
Image/Diagram Description: Passage about puppy traits and genetics.
Choices: A) cover your legs with a sturdy material called denim, B) carry information that gives living things certain traits, C) give parents information about what to name their puppy, D) make sure all puppies are born with the same color fur
Scenario Justification: Rich reading passage about genetics inheritance and trait variation in puppies.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Obtaining Evaluating and Communicating Information' — reading comprehension to extract scientific information.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of gene function from passage context.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Heavy reading comprehension focus. The passage is rich but the question is recall from text.

Stem: According to the passage the puppies have some of the same information in their genes. How does this affect the way they look?
Image/Diagram Description: Same puppy traits passage.
Choices: A) They all have the same short gray fur and black spots, B) They all like to play with the same toy, C) They all move in the same ways at the same exact times, D) They all have eyes ears noses four paws and small tails
Scenario Justification: Same rich passage. Students extract specific information about shared traits.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Obtaining Evaluating and Communicating Information' — finding supporting details in the passage.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that shared genes → shared physical features.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (same genes → same basic features across offspring).
Key Recommendation: Reading comprehension question. Could add data comparison between litters.

Stem: Read the sentences from the text about fur length in puppies. What conclusion can you draw from this evidence?
Image/Diagram Description: Same passage — excerpt about fur length variation.
Choices: A) Only parents with same exact genes can have puppies, B) You can have the gene for something and not show it, C) Puppies with the same parents look the exact same, D) Only adult dogs can have long hair because it needs to grow
Scenario Justification: Evidence-based conclusion drawing from passage text.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — drawing conclusions from textual evidence about gene expression.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that organisms can carry genes that are not expressed (recessive traits).
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (gene combination → some traits expressed, others not).
Key Recommendation: Good evidence-based reasoning from text. Students draw scientific conclusions from passage evidence.

Stem: Why do puppies from the same parents look different?
Image/Diagram Description: Same passage.
Choices: A) Parents get to pick which parent the puppy looks like, B) Each puppy chooses which parent to look more like, C) Puppy genes depend on the year they were born, D) Each puppy gets a different combination of genes which makes them look unique
Scenario Justification: Evidence-based reasoning about trait variation from the passage.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — explaining variation using the gene combination concept from the passage.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that different gene combinations from same parents → different traits.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (different gene combinations → different appearances).
Key Recommendation: Good concept. Could provide numerical trait data to support analysis.

Stem: What is the main idea of this text?
Image/Diagram Description: Same passage.
Choices: A) Puppies like humans are born with different gene combinations from their parents that help them look both alike and different, B) Dogs and humans have about 20000 genes and fur length can be determined by just one gene, C) Some physical characteristics are eye color fur color tail length height ear shape and teeth size, D) When a puppy's mother has short fur and father has long fur the puppy will have both
Scenario Justification: Main idea identification from a science passage.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Obtaining Evaluating and Communicating Information' — identifying the central message of a scientific text.
DCI Justification: Tests ability to synthesize passage information into a main idea about genetic inheritance.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: More reading comprehension than science assessment. The passage context is strong but the question assesses literacy.

Stem: A person kicks a soccer ball. The picture shows the path. Predict how the path will continue after step 5.
Image/Diagram Description: Image showing trajectory of a kicked soccer ball in an arc pattern.
Choices: A) It will go up, B) It will go down, C) It will go backward, D) It will stay in the air
Scenario Justification: Simple trajectory prediction from a visual pattern.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Using Mathematics and Computational Thinking' — predicting future motion based on observed trajectory pattern.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of gravity's effect on projectile motion.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (trajectory pattern → prediction) and Cause and Effect (gravity → downward motion).
Key Recommendation: Good prediction concept. Add data points showing velocity at each step for deeper analysis.

Stem: Find Louisiana on the map. What is the weather like in Louisiana on this map?
Image/Diagram Description: Weather temperature map of the United States.
Choices: A) below 0 degrees F, B) 50-59 degrees F, C) 40-49 degrees F, D) 70-79 degrees F
Scenario Justification: Map reading scenario. Students locate a state and read temperature data.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Data reading from a map.
DCI Justification: Tests ability to read a weather map. Basic application.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide multi-day weather maps and ask students to identify patterns or predict future weather.

Stem: Dora plans an investigation using one magnet to pick up paper clips. Which question can Dora answer by carrying out her investigation?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) What materials are used to make a magnet?, B) Why do paper clips bend easily if made from metal?, C) At what distance will the magnet be able to pick up the paper clips?, D) What touching forces are making the paper clips stick to the magnet?
Scenario Justification: Investigation planning scenario about magnet distance.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Planning and Carrying Out Investigations' — identifying which research question can be answered by a specific investigation.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of what can be investigated with the described setup.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (magnet distance → ability to attract clips).
Key Recommendation: Good investigation planning question. Add investigation data and ask students to analyze results.

Stem: Elena attaches a string to a ball and pulls it back. What can she predict the ball will do after it swings to the left side?
Image/Diagram Description: Image showing pendulum ball pulled back.
Choices: A) It will swing to the right side and then back to the left, B) It will stay on the left side, C) It will move higher each time it swings, D) It will stop in the middle before reaching the right side
Scenario Justification: Pendulum investigation scenario. Students predict oscillatory motion.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Using Mathematics and Computational Thinking' — predicting the pattern of pendulum motion.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of predictable patterns in motion (oscillation).
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (pendulum swings back and forth in predictable pattern).
Key Recommendation: Good prediction question. Add data about swing distances and times to deepen analysis.

Stem: Gia bounces a ball. Each bounce it goes less high. At the middle of the playground it bounces half as high as the first bounce. What happens by the far side?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) The ball would soon stop bouncing, B) The ball would pick up speed, C) The ball would stay in the air longer, D) The ball would roll back to the student
Scenario Justification: Bouncing ball scenario with decreasing height pattern described.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Using Mathematics and Computational Thinking' — extending the decreasing bounce pattern to predict the outcome.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that energy dissipation causes bounces to decrease until stopping.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (each bounce lower → eventually stops) and Cause and Effect.
Key Recommendation: Good prediction from pattern. Add bounce height data and ask for more precise prediction.

Stem: City leaders want to sort through landfill for recyclable metal cans. Engineers build a big magnet above trash piles. What will happen?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) The magnet will draw the metal cans up and out of the trash piles, B) The magnet will cause metal cans to move to the side into a neat pile, C) The magnet will flatten and recycle the cans while being collected, D) The magnet will pick up all the paper out of the pile
Scenario Justification: Applied engineering scenario about using magnetism for recycling.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — predicting the outcome of an engineering solution.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of magnetic attraction applied to problem solving.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (magnet above → attracts metal cans upward).
Key Recommendation: Good applied context. Add data comparing different separation methods.

Stem: What animal inspired biomimicry engineers to build this baby carrier?
Image/Diagram Description: Image of a baby carrier.
Choices: A) elephant, B) zebra, C) kangaroo, D) butterfly
Scenario Justification: Biomimicry scenario connecting animal adaptation to human engineering.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Simple analogy recognition.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of biomimicry concept — matching animal feature to human design.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (kangaroo pouch → baby carrier design).
Key Recommendation: Provide multiple biomimicry examples with data about design effectiveness.

Stem: These seeds have spiky edges that make them stick to each other. What invention did they inspire biomimicry engineers to make?
Image/Diagram Description: Image of spiky seeds (burdock).
Choices: A) iPhone, B) yeti cup, C) velcro, D) ear buds
Scenario Justification: Biomimicry scenario — seeds inspiring Velcro.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Simple analogy recall.
DCI Justification: Tests knowledge of the biomimicry origin of Velcro.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: This is more trivia than science. Provide data about hook-and-loop adhesion strength.

Stem: Biodiversity passage: What might the author be trying to communicate in these sentences about the web of life?
Image/Diagram Description: Long passage about biodiversity from AMNH with text about genes species and ecosystems.
Choices: A) The author wants the reader to realize that all species depend on each other for survival, B) The author wants the reader to know there are lots of animals, C) The author wants the reader to know all plants need animals to survive, D) The author wants the reader to realize you need the water cycle to cause weather
Scenario Justification: Rich reading passage about biodiversity with multiple types of information.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Obtaining Evaluating and Communicating Information' — interpreting the author's message from textual evidence.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of ecological interdependence from a science text.
CCC Justification: Engages Systems and System Models (interconnected web of species).
Key Recommendation: Good passage comprehension. More literacy than science assessment. Could add biodiversity data.

Stem: What is one way that the U.S. Forest Service protects the Sierra Nevada yellow-legged frogs?
Image/Diagram Description: Long passage about invasive bullfrogs and eDNA from ReadWorks.
Choices: A) by removing the invasive bullfrog species that threatens the frog, B) by telling the frogs to leave and find a new home, C) by building protected houses for the frogs, D) [truncated]
Scenario Justification: Rich reading passage about conservation eDNA and invasive species.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Obtaining Evaluating and Communicating Information' — extracting specific information from a science passage.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of conservation strategies from passage evidence.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: More reading comprehension than science. The passage is scientifically rich but the question tests recall.

Stem: What can you conclude about the information researchers get from eDNA based on the passage?
Image/Diagram Description: Same invasive species passage.
Choices: A) It helps them protect invasive species like the American bullfrog, B) It is not very reliable so they have to double-check, C) It is really interesting to study but not very important, D) It helps them locate the frog which will help them protect it
Scenario Justification: Continuation of the eDNA passage. Students draw conclusions about eDNA utility.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — drawing conclusions about eDNA's value based on passage evidence.
DCI Justification: Requires synthesizing information about eDNA methodology and its conservation applications.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (eDNA → species location → protection plans).
Key Recommendation: Good evidence-based conclusion from passage. Students synthesize information across paragraphs.

Stem: Based on the physical characteristics observed in the image select the correct statement about this animal's teeth — this animal eats __.
Image/Diagram Description: Image of animal skull/teeth.
Choices: A) meat, B) cheese, C) plants, D) only water
Scenario Justification: Visual observation of tooth structure to infer diet.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — using structural evidence to infer organism behavior.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of structure-function relationship between teeth and diet.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (flat teeth → plant eater).
Key Recommendation: Good concept. Provide data comparing tooth types across multiple animals and their diets.

Stem: Why might flamingos live in large groups? Select two that apply.
Image/Diagram Description: Passage and cause-and-effect chart about flamingo behavior from a biologist's observations.
Choices: A) to reproduce, B) to change color, C) to make many nests, D) to stay safe from predators, E) to collect the most pink feathers
Scenario Justification: Rich observational data from a biologist with a cause-and-effect chart about flamingo group behavior.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — using the cause-and-effect chart to identify the reasons for group behavior.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of multiple benefits of group behavior.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (living in groups → reproduction success + predator safety).
Key Recommendation: Good multi-select with data source. Could add quantitative data on group size and survival rates.

Stem: Why do African wild dogs live in packs?
Image/Diagram Description: Passage with bullet points about African wild dog pack behavior.
Choices: A) to reproduce in the pack, B) to chase down and trap their prey, C) to communicate with sneeze sounds, D) so that a male and female dog can be in charge at the same time
Scenario Justification: Detailed informational passage about African wild dog pack behavior with specific behavioral observations.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — identifying the primary reason for pack behavior from detailed passage evidence.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of why group behavior is advantageous for hunting success.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (pack hunting → successful prey capture).
Key Recommendation: Good passage-based question. Could add data comparing hunting success rates solo vs pack.

Stem: Cactus have deep roots to get water from underground. They can tolerate lots of sunshine and warm temperatures. Which environment will they most likely survive in?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) tropical rain forest, B) snowy mountain, C) desert, D) arctic tundra
Scenario Justification: Brief description of cactus adaptations. Students match to appropriate environment.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Simple matching.
DCI Justification: Tests basic understanding of organism-environment matching.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data on cactus survival rates in different environments.

Stem: In the book Earthworms Underground it says the earthworm's skin needs to be damp. What do you think the word 'damp' means?
Image/Diagram Description: Passage excerpt about earthworms.
Choices: A) heavily wet with oil, B) mildly wet with water, C) not wet at all, D) only water with no soil
Scenario Justification: Vocabulary question with passage context.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Vocabulary recall from context.
DCI Justification: Tests vocabulary not science understanding. Below grade-level depth for science assessment.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: This is a reading comprehension question not a science question. Replace with investigation about earthworm habitat preferences.

Stem: Marmots have dark fur which is adaptive on dark mountain rocks. After snow falls how is the dark fur now a non-adaptive trait?
Image/Diagram Description: Passage about marmots golden eagles and glaciers.
Choices: A) The dark fur is still adaptive — it is the best kind of fur, B) The dark fur is easier to see in the white environment making it harder to avoid predators, C) The dark fur keeps the marmot warmer and makes it easier to find water, D) The dark fur is non-adaptive because it is not the prettiest
Scenario Justification: Rich scenario about seasonal change in adaptive value of a trait. Students reason about how environmental change affects adaptation.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — explaining how environmental change (snow) alters the adaptive value of a trait (dark fur).
DCI Justification: Requires understanding that adaptation is context-dependent — a trait that helps in one environment may be harmful in another.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (snow → dark fur more visible → increased predation risk) and Stability and Change.
Key Recommendation: Excellent question about context-dependent adaptation. Rich scenario with clear reasoning required.

Stem: Two girls are swinging on a swing set. Each girl moves back and forth several times. What prediction can we make about how the girls will move in the future?
Image/Diagram Description: Image of two girls on swings.
Choices: A) One swing is faster than the other, B) One girl moves farther than the other, C) The motion of each swing is a back and forth pattern, D) One swing is blue and one is red
Scenario Justification: Simple observation scenario about predictable motion patterns.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Pattern recognition at basic level.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that swinging follows a predictable back-and-forth pattern.
CCC Justification: Engages Patterns (repetitive back-and-forth motion is predictable).
Key Recommendation: Add timing data for multiple swings and ask students to predict the period of the next swing.

Stem: A family built a 'family scooter' and needs to see if it will work. What stage of the scientific design process are they doing now?
Image/Diagram Description: None
Choices: A) planning, B) building, C) revising, D) testing
Scenario Justification: No scenario context. Simple identification of an engineering design stage.
SEP Justification: No practice engagement. Recall of design process stages.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of the engineering design process stages.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide data from a full engineering design cycle and ask students to analyze decisions at each stage.

Stem: Scientists realize lifting a boulder off the ground will give them the most access to a cave. What kind of force would they need?
Image/Diagram Description: Passage and image about scientists trying to access a cave blocked by a boulder.
Choices: A) a force similar to gravity, B) a force weaker than gravity, C) a force stronger than gravity, D) a magnetic force
Scenario Justification: Rich scenario about accessing a cave blocked by a boulder.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about force requirements relative to gravity.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that lifting an object requires overcoming gravity with greater force.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (force stronger than gravity → boulder lifts).
Key Recommendation: Good applied force reasoning. Add mass data and ask for more quantitative reasoning.

Stem: Which statement about the forces acting on the boulder is true?
Image/Diagram Description: Same cave-boulder scenario.
Choices: A) The forces are balanced, B) The forces are unbalanced, C) There are no forces acting on the boulder, D) The boulder is magnetic
Scenario Justification: Continuation of the boulder scenario. Students analyze forces on a stationary object.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Constructing Explanations' — reasoning about why the boulder is stationary (balanced forces).
DCI Justification: Tests understanding that a stationary object has balanced forces acting on it.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (balanced forces → no motion).
Key Recommendation: Good companion to Q25. Together they explore force concepts in context.

Stem: Two calves born to same parents go to different dairy farms. Select the correct statement from options.
Image/Diagram Description: Data table comparing two farms' conditions and two calves' characteristics.
Choices: A) Cows that eat more food produce less milk, B) Cows that weigh more produce more milk, C) Cows that live in cooler temperatures produce more milk, D) Black cows make different amounts of milk
Scenario Justification: Controlled comparison scenario with data table comparing two farm environments and cow outcomes.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — using controlled comparison data to identify the environmental factor affecting the outcome.
DCI Justification: Requires analyzing data with multiple variables to identify which environmental factor influences milk production.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (cooler temperature → more milk production) and Patterns.
Key Recommendation: Strong data analysis question with controlled comparison. Students must identify the correct variable.

Stem: Based on the physical characteristics observed in the image select the correct statement about dogs.
Image/Diagram Description: Image showing multiple dogs with different traits.
Choices: A) All dogs have the same traits, B) Some traits in a species are similar and some traits have variation, C) All traits in a species are similar, D) No traits in a species have variation
Scenario Justification: Visual observation of trait variation in dogs.
SEP Justification: No meaningful practice. Simple observation from image.
DCI Justification: Tests understanding of trait variation within a species.
CCC Justification: No CCC engagement.
Key Recommendation: Provide quantitative trait data across multiple individuals and ask students to analyze variation patterns.

Stem: A builder compares roof designs for a house in an area with high winds. Which statements best describe a design that will protect the roof? Select two.
Image/Diagram Description: Diagrams of three roof designs with wind flow patterns shown.
Choices: A) The best design stops the greatest amount of wind from blowing across the roof, B) The best design allows the roof to stay on the house even when strong winds blow, C) The design of roof 1 is best because wind blows past the walls, D) The design of roof 2 is best because no wind is trapped, E) The design of roof 3 is best because very little wind is trapped
Scenario Justification: Engineering design scenario with three roof designs and wind flow diagrams showing how wind interacts with each design.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Designing Solutions' — evaluating engineering designs based on wind-flow data visualizations.
DCI Justification: Requires analyzing wind-flow diagrams to determine which design best withstands high winds.
CCC Justification: Engages Structure and Function (roof shape → wind interaction → structural integrity).
Key Recommendation: Excellent engineering design question with visual data. Students analyze wind-flow patterns to select best design.

Stem: Students investigate how heat affects salvia plants. Figure 1 shows results at different temperatures. Graphs show Leesville Louisiana temperature and rainfall. In which month would salvia plants most likely grow best?
Image/Diagram Description: Figure 1: salvia plant growth at different temperatures. Graph 1: monthly high temperatures. Graph 2: monthly rainfall for Leesville Louisiana.
Choices: A) April, B) June, C) August, D) December
Scenario Justification: Rich multi-source scenario with experimental data (Figure 1) and real climate data (two graphs). Students must integrate three data sources to determine optimal growing conditions.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Analyzing and Interpreting Data' — integrating data from three different sources (experimental results and two climate graphs) to make a prediction.
DCI Justification: Requires understanding of plant-environment relationships and applying experimental data to real-world climate conditions.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (temperature + rainfall → plant growth) and Patterns (matching optimal conditions to months).
Key Recommendation: Excellent multi-source data integration question. Students synthesize experimental and climate data.

Stem: Which evidence best supports the answer to Part A?
Image/Diagram Description: Same multi-source data.
Choices: A) The month has temperatures below 20°C and receives less than 10 cm of rain, B) The month has temperatures close to 25°C and receives between 10 and 15 cm of rain, C) The month has temperatures below 20°C and receives more than 15 cm of rain, D) The month has temperatures above 30°C and receives between 10 and 15 cm of rain
Scenario Justification: Follow-up evidence selection using the same multi-source data.
SEP Justification: Engages 'Engaging in Argument from Evidence' — selecting the evidence that best supports the answer by matching experimental optimal conditions to climate data.
DCI Justification: Requires connecting experimental data about optimal temperature to actual climate data to justify the answer.
CCC Justification: Engages Cause and Effect (temperature close to 25°C + adequate rainfall → best growth).
Key Recommendation: Excellent evidence justification question. Part A and B together form a strong assessment of multi-source data reasoning.
